review_title: Be VERY cautious, here is the REALITY
pros:
Great coworkers
Fairly flexible schedule as long as you're getting the job done
Very approachable senior management
The sensation that they care about the employees
Employees will complain about the benefits but in reality they're not bad
cons:
Honeywell is not on a hiring surge, they are quietly on a layoff surge. 50 this week, 50 more 2 weeks from now. Major attempt to keep it out of the public eye for fear it hits their stock price. Some is COVID related but there are big pockets where people are being told that their job is being off-shored or that if they want to maintain their employment they have to move. This is especially true in marketing and development.

Senior leadership has a desire to announce products WAY before they are market ready. "Just get it out there and fix it later." You get left dealing with very unhappy customers whose complaints fall on deft ears.

Very little vision within the rank and file. Blue and red is great but red and blue is confusing and whatever you do, don't bring up green!

Newer employees tend to be laid off first. Longer term employees can have zero value but they'll hang onto them and even promote them. Having worked for several Fortune 50 companies, this place exceeds the typical bureaucracy to a fault.

No new ideas unless they are from above and then they're spectacular...NOT

Development is slow, VERY expensive, poor quality and they do not listen to marketing. The Test organization is laughable, there is no interop testing between hardware and software solutions and they've approved release of products with known problems that would take months to resolve...but they hit their date!

Reduction in bonus percentages which has been significant over the past 5 years. You're grandfathered in as long as you do not change business unit. When that happens, you drop to the lower levels.

Pay at below market levels

pros:
Great pay - I make a really solid salary that is quite a bit above the average for my field. 
Peers are good people - people in general are good to work with! 
They recognize and reward performance, even though it’s a nasty cutthroat backstabby blame game world you have to figure out how to navigate.
cons:
Yelly management - procurement leadership is the worst I have experienced in an almost 20 year career (some of which has been experiencing a lot of yelly management). The level of intimidation and bullying is beyond the pale. 
Extremely toxic work environment - the expectation that you do 10 hours of meetings a day with no breaks and then work all night (days are like 17 hours just to almost get by) is insane. And Saturday morning 7:15 meetings?? For gods sake, sometimes a person might like to sleep in after having  daily week day 6:30 am meetings forced on them (finally wrapping up a day of meetings with a 6:00 pm prep for the next morning’s 6:30 beating by executives who should have better things to do). 
Selling your soul for good pay - see above. At least they pay well. I think the insanity they expect and the extreme toll it takes on your physical and mental well being is probably worth a $30k a year pay cut just to have some sanity and work life balance.

review_title: Terrible place to work wouldn't recommend
job_title: Multi Skilled Operator in Portsmouth, England
pros: Sick months full sick pay & 185 hours holiday
cons:
Got the sack on purpose due to favoritism, being on the same wage as foreign agency workers, & a whole bunch of other reasons. I was permanent & working there for just over 4 years. Bad management - no backbone to face problems. Favoritism - making favored staff permanent who are more useless than those that were not given the job. Bullying - members of staff just want to say bad things about others as they have nothing positive going on in their working & home lives. Company is losing money hand over fist - people going off sick left right & center & good for them too, might as well take full advantage of the full sickness pay. Bad quality produced leading to extreme cost & unnecessary levels of waste. Relentless levels of customer returns & maintenance bills. Quality engineers are useless, they are only there because the company cannot find better! I tell you what, give me a job there as a quality engineer, after all It was me who problem solved half the sensor failing issues to begin with. Without my expertise, efficiencies & multi-tasking abilities, this company has just lost the equivalent of two permanent members of staff. This scumbag company should be dealt with in a court of law & all the permanent employees that are forever stuck on national minimum wage should get together with the staff associates, then go on strike & form a protest outside the factory in disgust that they are been taken for a ride by remaining on the lowest possible wage, the same as a temp worker who has just walked in from Romania with a terrible understanding of the English language. Then get your mobile phones out & report this terrible company to the BBC News channel. Absolutely disgraceful! Never known a company like it & am so happy that I am no longer there.

Can see this company collapsing in the next one to two years & quite rightly so, good riddance!

They will do anything to meet op income. No effort toward any other metrics. No vision beyond the end of the week or end of the month. An aerospace company that does not invest in manufacturing, quality or improving their horrible products. Every year, 8 to 10% of employees are put in the “lower elbow”, meaning no pay increase and no bonus. They say no quotas, but if a plan was submitted with less than 8%, it would get rejected until more people are assessed as “below standard”. Products development is horrible. Not validated beyond sample of 1 or 2, and they keep on pushing junk out the door. These are aerospace products for goodness sake. Makes me afraid to fly! They say they value employees because it’s the politically correct thing to do. They do not walk the talk. Not possible to have any less respect for your employees. DO NOT WORK HERE !

review_title: Once a leader in Buliding Controls, now just hanging on.
pros: None, Can't think of one.
cons: I worked for this company for 28 years. Wish I would have left earlier. They have just about destroyed their building controls ACS division, starting with the dissolving of the R&D department in Arlington heights. With Kevin Gilligan at the lead, they further wiped out the service dept, and never recovered. With No R&D, and buying anyone they can get their hands on to make up for it, they have not really produced ANYTHING in the building controls industry worth a good wet fart. Their motto in the 80s were "Our people are our most valuable asset", but with Cote pulling down ungodly bonuses while they cut back more and more on the little guys pay and benefits, the motto should be changed to "Our stockholders are our most valuable asset". The ACS division is so worried about anyone taking the little share of market they have left, that they lock down their controls as tight as possible to make it as hard as hell for other companies to take over their jobs, which are very poorly maintained and serviced. My feelings on this company: the ACS division of Honeywell is a poor choice for anyone looking for building automation.  There are many companies out there that will outperform this dying dinosaur hands down, and at a much better price.

pros: Access to new customers and great potential for technology creation

pros: The one-star reviews are understandably emotional and reactive. I give it 3 stars because it still has a ton of extremely knowledgeable and capable engineers, scientists, and technicians. There are a lot of great people here who make work more enjoyable. The company has a robust history as an industry leading liscensor of refining technology. It is not burning to the ground and will rebound as the oil market picks up.
cons: However, it likely won't return to its former excellence. Misguided cost savings initiatives are damaging the quality of service, engineering, and likely R&D. Poor compensation, overworking employees, and lay-offs are degrading the depth of experience, especially as lots of older employees will be retiring along with their extensive experience. Field advisors are being put in charge of commissioning projects with very little experience because nobody sticks around long enough. Management only shows concern for the short-term profits for shareholders. Employees have been asked to shoulder all the burden of trying to meet absurd revenue targets, while overall the company has still been very profitable. It is a result of Honeywell trying to squeeze everything it can out of the company; when it stops being profitable UOP will likely be divested.

review_title: Honeywell has ruined the reputation of Intelligrated
pros: Some interesting new technologies have been worked on, but these are never properly developed into marketable products. There were a lot of talented people in the company that were great resources for young engineers to learn from, but they have almost all left the company at this point.
cons:
After the Honeywell purchase, I had concern about layoffs. After speaking to several people that had been through their own Honeywell acquisitions, the consensus was they would make some leadership changes, but keep most everyone else on payroll. BUT I was also told "people will just leave." I thought this to be an interesting statement, yet it has proven to be 100% accurate. Over the years following the acquisition, all the senior leadership was replaced with corporate lackeys that did not share the previous management style that had fostered the tremendous growth of the company and sense of belonging for employees. Gone were the friendly and engaged conversations between upper management and lower level employees, replaced with the corporate BS so commonplace in multinationals like Honeywell. Honeywell is 100% focused on shareholder satisfaction, and 0% of employees. Townhall after townhall meeting employee concerns were dismissed, and well respected employees (including company founders) that had departed were badmouthed by high-level speakers. Company focus shifting to shareholder satisfaction over customer satisfaction meant the quality of product and support of products suffered substantially. Intelligrated always prided itself on being “one of the most desirable places to work in Cincinnati.” Interestingly, post-Honeywell the 3rd party surveys were no longer distributed.
As far as compensation goes, base pay was decent. Profit sharing had been part of compensation pre-Honeywell, but it was taken away. 401k matching went up(marginally) to a pretty decent level, BUT only if you remained for the entire year. Vesting went from day 1 to 3 years. Vacation went from a standard years-of-service based increase to “unlimited” vacation. Most people handled this reasonably, and continued to take similar time off, but some individuals took advantage of the situation. This prompted departmental changes to limit the unlimited vacation, directly against the corporate policy. It also meant that you would no longer get vacation paid out if it was remaining when you left the company. Raises also mostly became mostly non-existent. Very limited pools of money were made available for managers to distribute to their employees, so even exemplary performance would net a raise barely equal to cost-of-living increases.
As far as actual working conditions, these started high, but have been moving (quickly) in a downward direction since Honeywell. There were a number of large projects that were handled by my group, and while some of these required lots of extra working hours, the premium pay compensation was decent. I left before the new policy of 48+ went into effect. When I started we were 100% domestic and had great working relationships with other engineering groups throughout the country. The Honeywell changes pushed a lot of engineering efforts to “LQRs” (low quality regions), and that relegated domestic engineers to be project managers with constantly changing “resources” based in India. Constantly changing team members meant a big reduction in productivity, and many projects could not be completed on schedule due to bringing the new people up to speed almost weekly. There was also a big difference in the quality of work and vested interest in the product. I signed up to be a design engineer, not a project manager, so that change was a big negative for me. There was a constant battle between product engineers and “cost out”(make it in China) engineers that wanted to cheapen up the products, without regard for the quality of the finished product. Components were looked at singly, rather than at a system level. The cost-out work(including very nasty “negotiations” over pricing) resulted in many longstanding great working relationships with suppliers being destroyed. One specific example from a 15+ year supplier was “don’t ever f-ing call me again.” There were also wedges pushed between the different product groups, with favoritism being overtly blatant. Only managers pets got promotions; everyone else was stagnated in position. The only options were lateral moves to work on different products, or to other engineering groups.
In short, Honeywell destroyed the company that I had fully planned on retiring from, and I have a number of years of work remaining. I wish others still remaining there the best of luck, but would suggest looking elsewhere for a company that cares about it’s employees. I have been overwhelmingly happy since leaving; I knew I didn’t like it there, but didn’t fully realize how bad it was until I left.

review_title: Be VERY cautious, here is the REALITY
pros:
Great coworkers
Fairly flexible schedule as long as you're getting the job done
Very approachable senior management
The sensation that they care about the employees
Employees will complain about the benefits but in reality they're not bad
cons:
Honeywell is not on a hiring surge, they are quietly on a layoff surge. 50 this week, 50 more 2 weeks from now. Major attempt to keep it out of the public eye for fear it hits their stock price. Some is COVID related but there are big pockets where people are being told that their job is being off-shored or that if they want to maintain their employment they have to move. This is especially true in marketing and development.

Senior leadership has a desire to announce products WAY before they are market ready. "Just get it out there and fix it later." You get left dealing with very unhappy customers whose complaints fall on deft ears.

Very little vision within the rank and file. Blue and red is great but red and blue is confusing and whatever you do, don't bring up green!

Newer employees tend to be laid off first. Longer term employees can have zero value but they'll hang onto them and even promote them. Having worked for several Fortune 50 companies, this place exceeds the typical bureaucracy to a fault.

No new ideas unless they are from above and then they're spectacular...NOT

Development is slow, VERY expensive, poor quality and they do not listen to marketing. The Test organization is laughable, there is no interop testing between hardware and software solutions and they've approved release of products with known problems that would take months to resolve...but they hit their date!

Reduction in bonus percentages which has been significant over the past 5 years. You're grandfathered in as long as you do not change business unit. When that happens, you drop to the lower levels.

Pay at below market levels

pros:
Great pay - I make a really solid salary that is quite a bit above the average for my field. 
Peers are good people - people in general are good to work with! 
They recognize and reward performance, even though it’s a nasty cutthroat backstabby blame game world you have to figure out how to navigate.
cons:
Yelly management - procurement leadership is the worst I have experienced in an almost 20 year career (some of which has been experiencing a lot of yelly management). The level of intimidation and bullying is beyond the pale. 
Extremely toxic work environment - the expectation that you do 10 hours of meetings a day with no breaks and then work all night (days are like 17 hours just to almost get by) is insane. And Saturday morning 7:15 meetings?? For gods sake, sometimes a person might like to sleep in after having  daily week day 6:30 am meetings forced on them (finally wrapping up a day of meetings with a 6:00 pm prep for the next morning’s 6:30 beating by executives who should have better things to do). 
Selling your soul for good pay - see above. At least they pay well. I think the insanity they expect and the extreme toll it takes on your physical and mental well being is probably worth a $30k a year pay cut just to have some sanity and work life balance.

review_title: Terrible place to work wouldn't recommend
job_title: Multi Skilled Operator in Portsmouth, Isle of Wight, South East England, England
pros: Sick months full sick pay & 185 hours holiday
cons:
Got the sack on purpose due to favoritism, being on the same wage as foreign agency workers, & a whole bunch of other reasons. I was permanent & working there for just over 4 years. Bad management - no backbone to face problems. Favoritism - making favored staff permanent who are more useless than those that were not given the job. Bullying - members of staff just want to say bad things about others as they have nothing positive going on in their working & home lives. Company is losing money hand over fist - people going off sick left right & center & good for them too, might as well take full advantage of the full sickness pay. Bad quality produced leading to extreme cost & unnecessary levels of waste. Relentless levels of customer returns & maintenance bills. Quality engineers are useless, they are only there because the company cannot find better! I tell you what, give me a job there as a quality engineer, after all It was me who problem solved half the sensor failing issues to begin with. Without my expertise, efficiencies & multi-tasking abilities, this company has just lost the equivalent of two permanent members of staff. This scumbag company should be dealt with in a court of law & all the permanent employees that are forever stuck on national minimum wage should get together with the staff associates, then go on strike & form a protest outside the factory in disgust that they are been taken for a ride by remaining on the lowest possible wage, the same as a temp worker who has just walked in from Romania with a terrible understanding of the English language. Then get your mobile phones out & report this terrible company to the BBC News channel. Absolutely disgraceful! Never known a company like it & am so happy that I am no longer there.

Can see this company collapsing in the next one to two years & quite rightly so, good riddance!

pros: Paycheck when not on furlough
cons: Worst place I ever worked. Good people, horrible Leadership and leadership culture. 9 reductions in force in 4 years. In between RIFs you get unpaid furloughs. They will do anything to meet op income. No effort toward any other metrics. No vision beyond the end of the week or end of the month. An aerospace company that does not invest in manufacturing, quality or improving their horrible products. Every year, 8 to 10% of employees are put in the “lower elbow”, meaning no pay increase and no bonus. They say no quotas, but if a plan was submitted with less than 8%, it would get rejected until more people are assessed as “below standard”. Products development is horrible. Not validated beyond sample of 1 or 2, and they keep on pushing junk out the door. These are aerospace products for goodness sake. Makes me afraid to fly! They say they value employees because it’s the politically correct thing to do. They do not walk the talk. Not possible to have any less respect for your employees. DO NOT WORK HERE !

review_title: Once a leader in Buliding Controls, now just hanging on.
pros: None, Can't think of one.
cons: I worked for this company for 28 years. Wish I would have left earlier. They have just about destroyed their building controls ACS division, starting with the dissolving of the R&D department in Arlington heights. With Kevin Gilligan at the lead, they further wiped out the service dept, and never recovered. With No R&D, and buying anyone they can get their hands on to make up for it, they have not really produced ANYTHING in the building controls industry worth a good wet fart. Their motto in the 80s were "Our people are our most valuable asset", but with Cote pulling down ungodly bonuses while they cut back more and more on the little guys pay and benefits, the motto should be changed to "Our stockholders are our most valuable asset". The ACS division is so worried about anyone taking the little share of market they have left, that they lock down their controls as tight as possible to make it as hard as hell for other companies to take over their jobs, which are very poorly maintained and serviced. My feelings on this company: the ACS division of Honeywell is a poor choice for anyone looking for building automation.  There are many companies out there that will outperform this dying dinosaur hands down, and at a much better price.

review_title: Great global company with great people and stable environments
pros: Amazing people and culture where people are kind and helpful to each other. Despite some busy periods here and there, the company has excellent work and life balance in general.
cons: The company was gradually shifting to an off-shore model focusing on cost-cutting rather than generating new revenues and margins from innovations. It is difficult to progress in a career in certain disciplines. Similar issues with many large corporations, innovative ideas are hard to execute and often bound to legacy solutions and thinkings.

pros: The one-star reviews are understandably emotional and reactive. I give it 3 stars because it still has a ton of extremely knowledgeable and capable engineers, scientists, and technicians. There are a lot of great people here who make work more enjoyable. The company has a robust history as an industry leading liscensor of refining technology. It is not burning to the ground and will rebound as the oil market picks up.
cons: However, it likely won't return to its former excellence. Misguided cost savings initiatives are damaging the quality of service, engineering, and likely R&D. Poor compensation, overworking employees, and lay-offs are degrading the depth of experience, especially as lots of older employees will be retiring along with their extensive experience. Field advisors are being put in charge of commissioning projects with very little experience because nobody sticks around long enough. Management only shows concern for the short-term profits for shareholders. Employees have been asked to shoulder all the burden of trying to meet absurd revenue targets, while overall the company has still been very profitable. It is a result of Honeywell trying to squeeze everything it can out of the company; when it stops being profitable UOP will likely be divested.

review_title: Good for 5 years then move out
pros:
-Great to work with technical people in the engineering and across the organization
- good to gain initial experience of processes and front end design
-if lucky and Managements is in your favor, you can work in other group to get broad of experience by rotating to other subgroup
cons:
-long list of cons
-It is all about cuts and pinching every penny from employees all the time, and then customer, shareholders are their top priority as upper managements bonus depends on probably by shareholder's happiness and stock price
-local managements is just puppets of upper top down managements or at least that is how they play with some employees 
-doubtful if HR here is a neutral entity 
-pension cut, 401k cut and denial if you leave or X'ed before Dec 15, bonus cut, well deserved salary cuts, furloughs, layoff all these are very routine at uop honeywell. It happens every 3-4 years so whatever 1-3 % raise you may have gotten over the 2-3 years will get wiped out instantly with 10-20% paycut+raise-cut on the 3rd or 4th year
-management ladder moves way faster  than technical ladder, people in management changes positions every 2-3 years so engineers loses their race or slows down to reach their progression or promotion as they have to prove their capabilities to new manager who has no clue of the business and Technologies at least first 2 years by then on 3rd yr he or she makes another jump or furlough/layoff is waiting 
-lots of buddy-buddy politics even at director and sr management levels and this puts incompetent managements/directors in charge who have no real contribution to the growth of the company per dollar paid and have no uop kind of technological knowledge and does not do any good for the employees working under their group
-people who boot-lick to management get favors, progression faster, gets saved during RIF
-company policies are not applied equally to all employees some get standing desk easily while other have to justify and presented with budget cut excuse, some allowed to work remotely completely while other cant even work couple days per week remotely or had to quite over it b/c it did not workout with their family situation 
-everything getting out sourced to India and China 
-engineering management at all level very incompetent cant stand for their employees, they try to save their job and only the messenger of top down messages and not two ways and full of nonsense
-it seems that people who are not doing active actual engineering work are part of decision making team that sets the work process and makes design update or decision which does not help design engineers to get the way they envision the work process base on their experience  and the issue they face on active job
-managers and their buddies spend hours out on lunch and chit-chat 
-except for few, many PMs are just a joke have no management skills, just say yes to all from customer and keep pushing on bottom of the barrel design engineers
-vacation policy is so called unlimited, new person gets to use 4-5 weeks vs people with 15-20 year also get 4 week so it all depends on work load so if that gets screwed up your vacation gets screwed up to

review_title: Honeywell has ruined the reputation of Intelligrated
pros: Some interesting new technologies have been worked on, but these are never properly developed into marketable products. There were a lot of talented people in the company that were great resources for young engineers to learn from, but they have almost all left the company at this point.
cons:
After the Honeywell purchase, I had concern about layoffs. After speaking to several people that had been through their own Honeywell acquisitions, the consensus was they would make some leadership changes, but keep most everyone else on payroll. BUT I was also told "people will just leave." I thought this to be an interesting statement, yet it has proven to be 100% accurate. Over the years following the acquisition, all the senior leadership was replaced with corporate lackeys that did not share the previous management style that had fostered the tremendous growth of the company and sense of belonging for employees. Gone were the friendly and engaged conversations between upper management and lower level employees, replaced with the corporate BS so commonplace in multinationals like Honeywell. Honeywell is 100% focused on shareholder satisfaction, and 0% of employees. Townhall after townhall meeting employee concerns were dismissed, and well respected employees (including company founders) that had departed were badmouthed by high-level speakers. Company focus shifting to shareholder satisfaction over customer satisfaction meant the quality of product and support of products suffered substantially. Intelligrated always prided itself on being “one of the most desirable places to work in Cincinnati.” Interestingly, post-Honeywell the 3rd party surveys were no longer distributed.
As far as compensation goes, base pay was decent. Profit sharing had been part of compensation pre-Honeywell, but it was taken away. 401k matching went up(marginally) to a pretty decent level, BUT only if you remained for the entire year. Vesting went from day 1 to 3 years. Vacation went from a standard years-of-service based increase to “unlimited” vacation. Most people handled this reasonably, and continued to take similar time off, but some individuals took advantage of the situation. This prompted departmental changes to limit the unlimited vacation, directly against the corporate policy. It also meant that you would no longer get vacation paid out if it was remaining when you left the company. Raises also mostly became mostly non-existent. Very limited pools of money were made available for managers to distribute to their employees, so even exemplary performance would net a raise barely equal to cost-of-living increases.
As far as actual working conditions, these started high, but have been moving (quickly) in a downward direction since Honeywell. There were a number of large projects that were handled by my group, and while some of these required lots of extra working hours, the premium pay compensation was decent. I left before the new policy of 48+ went into effect. When I started we were 100% domestic and had great working relationships with other engineering groups throughout the country. The Honeywell changes pushed a lot of engineering efforts to “LQRs” (low quality regions), and that relegated domestic engineers to be project managers with constantly changing “resources” based in India. Constantly changing team members meant a big reduction in productivity, and many projects could not be completed on schedule due to bringing the new people up to speed almost weekly. There was also a big difference in the quality of work and vested interest in the product. I signed up to be a design engineer, not a project manager, so that change was a big negative for me. There was a constant battle between product engineers and “cost out”(make it in China) engineers that wanted to cheapen up the products, without regard for the quality of the finished product. Components were looked at singly, rather than at a system level. The cost-out work(including very nasty “negotiations” over pricing) resulted in many longstanding great working relationships with suppliers being destroyed. One specific example from a 15+ year supplier was “don’t ever f-ing call me again.” There were also wedges pushed between the different product groups, with favoritism being overtly blatant. Only managers pets got promotions; everyone else was stagnated in position. The only options were lateral moves to work on different products, or to other engineering groups.
In short, Honeywell destroyed the company that I had fully planned on retiring from, and I have a number of years of work remaining. I wish others still remaining there the best of luck, but would suggest looking elsewhere for a company that cares about it’s employees. I have been overwhelmingly happy since leaving; I knew I didn’t like it there, but didn’t fully realize how bad it was until I left.
